Question_1.Context: L-type amino acid transporters (LAT1) are known to be overexpressed in various cancers and play a crucial role in cancer growth and survival. Radiohalogen-labeled amino acid derivatives that target LAT1 can be used for cancer imaging and radiotherapy.
Question_1.Question: Which radiohalogen-labeled amino acid derivative exhibits instability against deastatination in vivo, posing a challenge for its use in radiotherapy?
Question_1.Source: However, 211At-labeled amino acid derivatives exhibit instability against deastatination in vivo, making it challenging to use 211At for radiotherapy.

Question_2.Context: In the development of radiopharmaceuticals, the stability of the compound against dehalogenation in vivo is a critical factor. Radiohalogen-labeled amino acid derivatives have been synthesized with high dehalogenation stability for use in radiotheranostics.
Question_2.Question: What is the primary reason for the instability of radiohalogen-labeled amino acid derivatives in vivo?
Question_2.Source: However, 211At-labeled amino acid derivatives are unstable in vivo and undergo deastatination, reportedly owing to weak carbon-astatine bond strength.

Question_3.Context: The neopentyl glycol (NpG) structure has been used as a scaffold for labeling radiohalogens due to its high steric hindrance and resistance to P450 metabolism, which contributes to the stability of the labeled compounds against dehalogenation in vivo.
Question_3.Question: What structural feature contributes to the high stability against dehalogenation in vivo of radiohalogen-labeled compounds using the NpG structure?
Question_3.Source: radiohalogen-labeled compounds using the NpG structure show high stability against dehalogenation in vivo owing to high steric hindrance and resistance to P450 metabolism.

Question_4.Context: Amino acid derivatives can be modified to be recognized as substrates by LAT1, which is essential for their uptake into cancer cells overexpressing LAT1.
Question_4.Question: Which part of the L-tyrosine molecule is expected to be acceptable for modification to ensure substrate recognition by LAT1?
Question_4.Source: According to the structures of radiolabeled amino acid derivatives such as [18F]-fluoroethyl-L-tyrosine ([18F]-FET), modification of the hydroxyl group of phenol in L-tyrosine is expected to be acceptable for substrate recognition by LAT1.

Question_5.Context: The development of radiohalogen-labeled amino acid derivatives involves the synthesis and characterization of these compounds for their specific cellular uptake and biodistribution in tumor-bearing models.
Question_5.Question: What is the purpose of synthesizing new radiohalogen-labeled amino acid derivatives?
Question_5.A: To decrease their stability in vivo
Question_5.B: To increase their recognition as substrates of LAT1
Question_5.C: To enhance their excretion from the body
Question_5.Source: radiohalogen-labeled amino acid derivatives ([211At]At-NpGT, [125I]I-NpGT, and [18F]F-NpGT; Fig. 1) were synthesized and characterized for their LAT1-specific cellular uptake and biodistribution in tumor-bearing mice.

Question_6.Context: In the context of radiotheranostics, it is crucial that the diagnostic and therapeutic agents exhibit similar pharmacokinetics in the body to ensure accurate diagnosis and effective treatment.
Question_6.Question: Why is it essential for radiotheranostic agents to have similar biodistributions?
Question_6.B: To increase the complexity of treatment
Question_6.C: To ensure accurate diagnosis and effective treatment
Question_6.D: To reduce the effectiveness of the agents
Question_6.Source: Ensuring similarity in the pharmacokinetics of diagnostic and therapeutic agents in the body is essential for their application in radiotheranostics.

Question_7.Context: The stability of radiolabeled compounds in biological media such as phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) and fetal bovine serum (FBS) is an important parameter in assessing their suitability for in vivo applications.
Question_7.Question: What is the significance of assessing the stability of radiolabeled compounds in PBS and FBS?
Question_7.B: To evaluate their stability for in vivo applications
Question_7.D: To assess their resistance to gamma radiation
Question_7.Source: All radiolabeled compounds showed high stability in PBS and FBS, and no halogen desorption was observed (< 1%).

Question_8.Context: The uptake and release of radiolabeled amino acid derivatives by tumor cells are indicative of their transport dynamics and potential for use in radiotheranostics.
Question_8.Question: What does the uptake and subsequent release of radiolabeled amino acid derivatives by tumor cells indicate?
Question_8.A: Their inability to be transported into cells
Question_8.B: Their transport dynamics and potential for radiotheranostics
Question_8.D: Their lack of recognition by LAT1
Question_8.Source: Cellular uptake of [211At]At-NpGT, [125I]I-NpGT, and [18F]F-NpGT by C6 glioma cells increased over time. Furthermore, these radiolabeled compounds were gradually excreted from the cells.

Question_9.Context: Inhibitors of the L-type amino acid transporter (LAT1) can be used to study the specificity of substrate recognition by LAT1, which is important for the development of targeted radiopharmaceuticals.
Question_9.Question: Which of the following is used as an inhibitor of LAT1 to study the specificity of substrate recognition?
Question_9.Source: The uptake of these radiolabeled compounds was significantly inhibited in the presence of BCH, an inhibitor of the L-type amino acid transporter.

Question_10.Context: The therapeutic efficacy of radiolabeled compounds in cancer treatment can be evaluated in animal models by observing their effect on tumor growth.
Question_10.Question: What is a method to evaluate the therapeutic efficacy of a radiolabeled compound in cancer treatment?
Question_10.A: Observing its effect on the growth of tumors in animal models
Question_10.D: Assessing its resistance to metabolic degradation
Question_10.Source: In this study, [211At]At-NpGT exhibited a dose-dependent inhibitory effect on the growth of glioma-bearing mice.
